snippet: F.B.I. agents recognized the stakes of any investigation tied to David H. Petraeus, the C.I.A. director who resigned Friday, but were wary of exposing a private affair with no criminal or security implications.
abstract: Government officials reveal that high-level officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Dept were notified in late summer of evidence that Central Intelligence Agency director David H Petraeus was involved in an extramarital affair; new accounts of events that led to Petraeus's sudden resignation shed light on the pressures that face FBI agents who recognize the high stakes of any such investigation but must be wary of exposing a private affair with no evident criminal or security implications.

byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and CHARLIE SAVAGE
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Michael R. Gordon.

lead_paragraph: F.B.I. agents recognized the stakes of any investigation tied to David H. Petraeus, the C.I.A. director who resigned Friday, but were wary of exposing a private affair with no criminal or security implications.

headline.seo: U.S. Officials Say Petraeus’s Affair Known in Summer
headline.main: Officials Say F.B.I. Knew of Petraeus Affair in the Summer
headline.print_headline: Timeline Shows F.B.I. Discovered Affair In Summer
